chapter.title: bLUe presentation
chapter.para: With bLUe you can correct and enhance the colors of your photos in a few clicks. bLUe uses adjusment layers to correct white balance, exposure, contrast, brightness, hue, saturation,...To achieve multiple corrections, you can add as many layers as you want and stack them in any order.
bLUe proposes a wide set of adjustment layers : exposure, contrast, color temperature, filters, cloning, segmentation, 1D LUTs and 3D LUTs.

1D LUT are represented by curves. Modifications are applied to each color channel individually. As a consequence, the same correction is applied to all pixels, regardless of their color, unless you use selection tools to choose the region of the image that needs a correction.

In contrast, a 3D LUT adjustment layer is represented by a set of color nodes. Modifications are applied to each pixel according to its true color. bLUe interactively constructs a 3D LUT adjusting the exact set of colors you chose. Other colors remain unmodified : no need for complex selection tools such as lasso or magic wands.

3D LUTS are widely used by professional film makers, but the lack of interactive tools made them poorly useful for photo enhancement as the shooting conditions may vary widely from an image to another. With bLUe, in a few clicks, you select the colors to modify, the corresponding 3D LUT is automatically built and applied to the image. You can then fine tune it as you want.
Any stack of adjustment layers can be saved in bLUe format. In addition, all adjustment layers but filters can be exported and imported in .cube format.
bLUe also provides a slide show mode.

section.title: Basic usage
section.para: Open Menu File and select an image file. bLUe can open usual color file formats : .jpg, .png, .tif, .bmp. Indexed and grayscale images cannot be edited. When it loads an image, bLUe saves the image metadata in a sidecar file, with the extension .mie.

By default, three adjustment layers are added to the document They are shown in the Layers right pane window. Clicking on a row displays the corresponding adjustment form:
Color Temperature corrects the white balance of the image, depending on the shooting conditions. Lower temperatures shift to warm colors (red), higher temperatures to cold colors (blue). Two methods of correction can be chosen : Photo Filter or Chromatic Adaptation. The second gives usually better results.
Exposure corrects too dark or too white images.
Contrast improves the local contrast of the image. Higher values for Clip Limit increase the contrast.
Image edition should always begin by tuning these three parameters. However, they can be adjusted at any time.

Preview Mode At the bottom of the "Layers" window, check Preview to enter the preview mode. With preview mode enabled (default), images can be displayed faster, especially for high resolution images. Uncheck Preview to display the full resolution image. Note that images are always saved with their full resolution.

section.title: Adding adjustment Layers
section.para: Choose Menu Layer -> New Adjustment Layer, and select a type of layer. The newly added layer is shown in the right pane window. and its name is editable. To toggle the layer visibility, click on its "Eye" icon.

listitem.para: Curves RGB : Channel based curves in the RGB color space,

Curves HSB and Curves HSpB : Hue, saturation, brightness curves. The HSB color model uses the classic brightness B = max(r, g, b) . THe HSpB color model uses the perceptive brightness pB=sqrt(alpha*r*r+beta*g*g+gamma*b*b), where alpha, beta and gamma are constant coefficients related to the differences in perception of red, green and blue colors by the human eye.
Curves Lab : Channel based curves in the Lab color space.
Filter: Sharpen, unsharp mask and gaussian blur

3D LUT HSB and 3D LUT HSpB : 3D LUT based adjustment layers. Both adjust hue and saturation and keep brightness (classic brightness for HSB layers and perceptive brightness for HSpB (see Curves HSB and curves HSpB above),
Cloning Layer: Seamless replacement of a region of the image by another, for example to erase an unwanted object.
Segmentation Layer: It automatically builds a mask to extract an obeject from the background.

section.para: Each layer is drawn on top of the underlying layers with its current opacity and composition mode
Layer opacity The layer opacity slider adjusts the opacity of the active layer.
Composition Mode Select a composition mode for the active layer. All standard composition modes are available, including Luminosity and Color.

Each layer owns a mask, disabled by default. It can be displayed as a color mask or an opacity mask.To enable a layer mask, Right Click -> Enable Mask on the layer row, and choose color or opacity mode. When the mask is enabled a red letter m is shown in the layer's row. Masks can be edited with the tool pens Mask and Unmask.

Grouping layers Multiple consecutive adjustment layers can be grouped. A group of layers shares a unique mask, allowing simultaneous mask edition. When layers are grouped, their mask is enabled and a | character is shown near the letter m in the layer pane.

Note. If the active layer and all upper layers do not share the same group, mask modifications will not be visible immediately. Then, to view these modifications while editing the mask, switch off the visibility of all upper layers.

section.title: Using 3D LUT HSB and HSpB adjustment layers
section.para: Select the layer in the "Layers" window, and make sure it is visible. The adjustment form displays a classical "hue-saturation" color wheel : the origin (neutral color) corresponds to the wheel centre, and fully saturated colors are on the periphery. All colors are displayed with the same brightness. It can be modified with the brightness slider below the color wheel.

On the left hand side image, click with the mouse a point whose color you want to change. A color node, or a set of neighbor color nodes is displayed on the form, as black circles. Each node represents a set of colors with constant hue and saturation, corresponding to the underlying color of the wheel. Node(s) can be dragged over the wheel to a position corresponding to the target colors you want to achieve. When the mouse is released, the selected colors are updated. Pixel brightness is kept unchanged.
Selecting nodes To select a set of nodes do one of the following :

listitem.para: Left click with the mouse pointer in an empty region of the color wheel, and drag the blue rectangular rubberband over the set of nodes to select
Ctrl-click on each node to select

section.para: Grouping nodes To group a set of nodes, select them and next, right click on any of the selected nodes to open the context menu and choose Group.

listitem.para: Add node : selected nodes are added to the current selection
Remove node : selected nodes are removed from the current selection
Select neighbors : the selected node and its neighbors are added to, or removed from, the current selection.
Reset removed nodes : nodes removed from the current selection are reset to their initial position and color
Show histogram : diusplay the 2D hue/saturation histogram of the image.
Use image : The transformation is applied to the whole image
Use selection : you can draw a rectangle on the image with the marquee tool and apply the transformation to the region limited by the rectangle.

section.title: Using Color Temperature adjustment layer
section.para:
Select the layer in the "Layers" right pane, and make sure it is visible. Two methods are available to modify the temperature of color for an image :
Photo Filter : It uses a monochrome image acting as a photo filter.
Chromatic Adaptation : It uses the Bradford - Von Kries method. See http://www.brucelindbloom.com/index.html?Eqn_ChromAdapt.html
Usually, Chromatic Adaptation gives better results.

section.title: Saving a document
section.para: Images can be saved in any usual color format, indexed formats excepted. By default bLUe does not overwrite the original file : it creates a new file, with suffix copy** and copies back the metadata from the sidecar to the new image file. The sidecar is not deleted.

section.title: Rating
section.para: A rating between 0 and 5 stars can be assigned to each image and saved in the sidecar as a XMP tag. Note that the rating is NOT written in the original image file. bLUe uses the value of the rating when playing a slide show (see Slide show below).

section.title: Playing a slide show
section.para: Open Menu Window -> Slide show, and select a folder. All .jpg and .png images from the selected folder and its subfolders are displayed in full screen mode.The slide show can be paused at any time by pressing the Escape key.
Several options are available via a context menu

listitem.para: Pause: pause the slide show (shortcut Escape key)
Resume: resume the previously paused slide show
Rating: Subsequent slide shows will not display images with 0 or 1 rating.
